Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Urban Adaptation and its Role in the Success of Biological Invasion in Anolis Lizards
Award.AbstractNarration:
Urban areas are expanding rapidly around the globe, resulting in drastic changes to the environment compared to natural landscapes: buildings and parking lots replace natural vegetation in cities. The urban environment, which encompasses a major portion of the US, directly affects the ecology and evolution of species, but little research has been conducted to understand the intensity and scope of these effects. Another critical dimension of global change is biological invasions, which threaten biodiversity worldwide. This project connects two important dimensions of global change to test a novel hypothesis that urban adaptation may increase the success of biological invasions, which often have dramatic ecological and economic effects on the invaded habitats. This award will also support the STEM training of a postdoctoral researcher and numerous graduate and undergraduate students. Curriculum materials will be developed for K-12 education and outreach efforts will target the urban areas where this research will be conducted and where the research team members live.

The way organisms interact with their environment is expected to drive intense natural selection on their morphology and behavior. This work will study the crested anole lizard, which is native to Puerto Rico but established via human-mediated introductions in several places outside its natural range. This research will use field and laboratory studies to first test the hypothesis that a widespread lizard species is adapted behaviorally, morphologically, and physiologically to urbanization. Second, the study will test if adaptation occurs at multiple life history stages, including embryos and juveniles. Lastly, the study will investigate a novel idea in invasion biology that adaptation to urban environments may predispose populations to become successful invaders of other urban areas, using molecular data to identify source populations. Detailed portions of the research will estimate thermal tolerance and examine behavioral thermoregulation in different habitats, use SNPs to identify the source population of the invaders, and examine habitat influence on development in the field. This research will help to establish whether or not adaptation to urban areas can facilitate the process of biological invasion, and will likely lead to conclusions that can be generalized across other urban tolerant species and biological invasions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Urban areas are expanding rapidly around the world, resulting in drastic changes to environmental conditions in cities as compared to natural habitats. We studied how urbanization alters various aspects of the environment relevant to the persistence and evolution of invasive lizards in Miami, Florida and San Juan, Puerto Rico. For example, urbanization transformed the structural habitat for lizards, removing ground vegetation and trees while at the same time adding artificial substrates, such as cement walls, metal posts and wood fences. Lizard locomotor performance was poor on these smooth, artificial substrates, leading to slower and less stable movement. The result in urban areas was that natural selection favored lizards with longer hindlimbs and larger toepads because lizards with these traits performed better on artificial surfaces. We also determined how urbanization changes the thermal environment available for lizards. Consistent with the urban heat island effect, we found urban areas and the lizards inhabiting them to be warmer than surrounding forested areas. These warmer conditions favored some invasive species, allowing them to achieve their preferred temperatures and likely contributing to their persistence and spread, but at the same time city temperatures constrained the ability of other species to occupy heavily urbanized areas. Overall, an important finding of this research was the consistent differences between urban and natural forest populations of lizards for a wide range of traits including behavior, ecology, morphology and physiology. Urbanization appears to be a strong selective force acting on urban populations and facilitates the persistence and spread of invasive populations of some species. 

 

Working in collaboration with Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden and Florida International University in Miami, FL, we developed a new educational module for the Fairchild Challenge program, which is an established, school-based environmental education program that actively involves students in environmental education and stewardship. Our "Lizards on the Loose" challenge started in 2014 engaged middle school students in active data collection on the ecology and natural history of local lizard species. Students collected, analyzed, and presented results of their ecological research on lizards found in their backyards, schoolyards and parks. For the project, we wrote a field guide to the local Anolis lizards in Miami and developed the data collection protocols for the various versions of the project administered each year. Our challenge was very popular with thousands of students from schools throughout the Miami metropolitan area participating over the five-year period (2014-2019). Students produced presentations, posters and videos explaining their results. We updated the project each year including surveys to evaluate temporal variation in daily activity and habitat use. Data were entered directly into Google spreadsheets to streamline the data management. We also developed this project into a broader citizen science project where people upload geo-referenced photos of lizards in Florida to iNaturalist and we plan to use these data to ask questions about changes in the distributions of invasive lizards in south Florida.
